Anonymous Thu 02 Nov 2017 16:39:56 No.12331933 Report
Quoted By: >>12332003 >>12332029 >>12332259 >>12332778 >>12333087
>>12331843
If you're seriously writing something that you have any intention of being read by more than one person once, then here is a couple rules:
>Basic grammar and punctuation rules are rules, not suggestions. I'd get on Strong about this more often, but at least he's constantly writing. Still, at least have proper capitalization.
>You are never done on your first draft. When you hit the end of your story the first time, you hit save, read through it, and then do a bit of landscaping. Trim the bits that drag on too long, and expand on the things that are relevant but you didn't know how to word when you wrote it the first time.
>Regarding actually finishing your first draft, I recommend the bulldozer method. Just fucking write, borderline stream of conscious style. Get words onto the paper/document and get it done. Afterwards, see tip 2.

Any other advice you'll have to be more specific about what you're troubled with. Oh, and:
>You're going to be shit at the start unless you're already experienced with long form writing by manner or reason. That's okay; writing is a skill like anything else, and you have to actively work at it to develop it. Just prepare to be lambasted for it, especially if you're posting it to 4chan of all places.

Anonymous Thu 02 Nov 2017 16:47:30 No.12332003 Report
Quoted By:
>>12331919
Well >>12331933 has some pretty good tips. If the “inspiration” part is bogging you down, then I have a few suggestions.

- Write from experience. A lot of writers here draw on real-world events for their greens. Don’t start writing about the life of a ____-war soldier unless you’re familiar with the subject or can research it. But don’t feel compelled to make the subject matter something grandiose either; there are a lot of nice slice-of-life greens here. Write what you know; it’ll be easier to think of details and plot points that way.

- Think of what you’d want to get out of your story. Lewd or comfy? Plot progression or just different scenarios for the characters to get in each others’ pants? Most of what you write should have the characters work toward these goals so you don’t derail the story.

Other tips would be a little vague but still useful. Read a lot of greens, watch some movies or TV shows, etc. Don’t be afraid to draw inspiration from media if you need to. If you like a certain show or video game, hey, maybe do a fanfic about it. We have several writers who’ve done that already.
Anonymous

Anonymous Thu 02 Nov 2017 18:44:58 No.12333087 Report
Quoted By:
>>12331933
> bulldozer method
This. There are many names for it, I call it writing vomit. Just get it out there first and fix things later. If you're ever done NaNoWriMo, just start like that. Keep a pocket sized notebook on hand at all times. I get my best ideas when I'm at work or half asleep trying to get up in the morning. Steal ideas from everything and everyone, I've written a short story based on a single line someone I used to be friends with said in a college class years ago. Think of writing like science: few people get to name new isotopes, but tons of people make new chemicals from existing elements. You are here to write what you can, and if you stumble upon a completely new take on life then congratulations. As you write, you will develop a style and a method. Experiment with that a bit. My method is to plan things in excruciating detail before writing and then derail from those plans half way through. 80% of what I write is never seen by the reader, but that's because I write like a Game Master. Other people are much more freeform. When you are done with the first draft, read it out loud, quietly if you have to. Some people (like me) can read right over blatant word mix ups and never notice unless we hear it out loud.

>>12333008
Don't panic too hard. I was an English tutor for a couple years, so if anything I'm only saying its bad because it's actually bad and not I DON'T LIKE IT SO IT'S SHIT
If I was grading what I'm reading, I'd dink you a couple points for improper word choice, and word flow could use some work as some of these sentences are robotic.
>"You stopped in your tracks but it was still getting closer."
You can make this more dramatic and/or interesting by detailing just how it's coming closer. Is it creeping? Is it floating along? Does it keep on trucking? Maybe it's, somehow, clawing towards me? How is it moving?
This is the kind of moment where you can make things come alive, rather than reading a drab police report.

>>12333085
>>12333118
>>12333036
As my English professor put it, "Semi-colons are not super powered commas. Instead they should be treated as adaptable periods." Another thing to keep in mind is to use them sparingly; (look at me being topical) they're rare enough that if you see one of them too often (like say, every paragraph) you'll notice them, and it might give your writing this intangible feeling of trying too hard.

Anonymous Thu 02 Nov 2017 19:24:58 No.12333485 Report
Quoted By:
>>12333288
There is no problem with writing like that in the first place, and if that's your comfort zone then by all means do so in your first or second draft. Still, you should revisit your writing before you send it off and give it a layer of color where it would be helpful. Frivolous writing has no place in reports that need to get information across as clearly as possible, but creative writing is where frivolous writing shines. It also creates one of the biggest issues in creative works.
Tell me every detail of the world you have made, but unless it's important, I don't need more than two sentences about the exact manner the paint is peeling off of the wall to describe a decrepit building. If the MC isn't particularly captivated by his lover's hair style, or the details of just how perfect her hime cut is isn't relevant to the story, then just give a sentence or two.
But goddamn if the MC (and thus, we the audience as well) has just jumped into a mecha cockpit, I want to know about the dials, the displays, the knobs, and the switches. How does the machine move? What color is the display shining in? Can you still hear the outside from within the cockpit, or is it quiet? Does it feel like a tomb or a womb? The key to creative writing is knowing when to keep the story shuffling along and when the bust your creative nut all over the current moment and paint a picture with it for the reader.

>>12333321

That being said, having a physical notebook (or a smart device with a keyboard you don't hate) on you while out and about is good for jotting down ideas when you can't sit down at your computer to hammer them out.

Anonymous Thu 02 Nov 2017 19:42:39 No.12333644 Report
Quoted By: >>12333793
>>12333456
I work from memory and employ others to proofread. Usually it isn't hard to find someone, and referencing your work sentence-by-sentence against a reference book will make you hate working on it. Also, while you definitely need to know the rules, the most important thing is to know the effect they have on the reader and his pacing. In prose, it's often best to not ruin good flow in the name of being technically correct. Poets hardly give a fuck at all, and, while it isn't our medium directly, prose writers generally still give some attention to rhythm and meter. I don't count anything out, but I do pay a lot of attention to the way the words play out as you read them. That I do by feel. My favorite way to cut corners for the sake of sound is actually semicolons: sometimes you get yourself into a position where you've got a lot of long, comma-heavy sentences going, and you need to break them up. Sometimes it's sloppy to go to independent sentences since they require you to bring up the subject again, but semicolon divided sentences read more like two short sentences than like a run-on. For deliberate grammar misuse, here's one I just did
>The girl didn't seem to be glaring for the same reasons she was. She was glaring back for the fun of it. Glaring to torture her. That was making things worse.
"Glaring to torture her" is a fragment, but it rings better to my ear, and, grouped with other progressively shortening statements, helps express anxiety on the part of the character.

Also Google docs is good shit. The best thing is you can work from your phone, which I do all the time.
>mfw 200 page document written at least 20% on phone

Anonymous Thu 02 Nov 2017 19:59:57 No.12333793 Report
Quoted By: >>12334011
>>12333644
>In prose, it's often best to not ruin good flow in the name of being technically correct.
This is often an understated truth about writing. Especially since traditional education focuses on maintaining proper grammar at all times, while giving reading assignments of books from authors who selectively choose when they give a fuck about proper sentence structure and when they don't.
It's some advanced shit and if you're still in the process of asking "How do I write good-er" then don't pay much mind to it, but really the only unbreakable rule of writing is that you can't change the rules of punctuation. A question mark is always a question mark, with all its roles, duties, and signifying properties. Other than that? Go fucking nuts; assuming your skill level allows the reader to still understand what you're on about, you can get away with some real nonsense. One word sentences one after another (noir novels do this often enough), or even making up words on the spot that are immediately understood thanks to the context provided (See: Snicker-snack). Hell, go full purple prose and dedicate a paragraph to every minor thing, if you really want to.
Just understand that these really should only be done by those who already know what they're doing, and thus know exactly with how much they can get away with to walk the balance of insane genius and shit writing. Sort of like free diving or rock climbing without a harness. It's basically how experts and experienced writers show off that yes, they're harder than the meanest bastard you can think of when it comes to their craft; anyone else who tries what they do will most likely fall short and make a fool of themselves.

Anonymous Thu 02 Nov 2017 20:24:16 No.12334011 Report
Quoted By: >>12334177
>>12333793
It's approachable, you just have to know why you're doing it and proofread for clarity. The whole point of grammar is to provide a structure with which to make sense. Making sense is the only real endgame, and sometimes, particularly when pushing to get across a certain impression, it can make MORE sense to cut a corner here and there. Use your sentence structure to make the reader feel things, just like everything else in the text. It's easiest when you can feel the emotions genuinely while you wrote, as the structure will follow. Your preferred intoxicant may help with this. It's workable anyway though, just reread and reread each sentence as you write it for flow and clarity. It will sound good or it won't, and if it doesn't, fuck with it until it does. Alternatively, keep going and fuck with it later

On the subject of emotion, pic related is a pet peeve of mine. The teachers explanation is bad and the intent is shortsighted. Symbolism is not profound, and it's not a wink-wink-nudge-nudge between writers to brag about how smart and profound they are. Some teachers present it like it's some kind of an intellectual in-joke that you have to be taught to understand and magically has value because it's abstract. That is not so. Symbolism is for everyone. You're only taught to recognize it to help you learn to write it. The real answer is the author didn't make the drapes blue to represent overwhelming depression, he did it because the character is depressed, and he knows describing a scene in terms of dark shades of blue will help us feel what the character is feeling because humans respond in predictable ways to imagery. The same story goes for abstract plot symbolism that might be used for foreshadowing or whatever. It's just impressionism. My point is, don't assume shit is necessarily over your head, and know there's no such thing as profundity in anything that isn't useful. Writing prose is about emotions, not fedora-tier Easter eggs.
Anonymous

Anonymous Thu 02 Nov 2017 20:41:07 No.12334177 Report
Quoted By:
>>12334011
>Plot symbolism
Ex. You've got an uptight protagonist. He's on time to everything and very responsible, but tightly wound and under a lot of stress. Life is hectic for him, and he never gets a chance to experience the world around him. He wears an expensive watch that he keeps in pristine condition.

One day he meets a (possibly furry) girl. They start spending a lot of time together. He forgets about hoe stressful and hectic life is when they're together. He loses track of time in her company. At work next week, someone comments his watch is dirty. Maybe he cleans it and doubles down, maybe he lets it be and keeps relaxing. Maybe he actually gets with this girl though. They grow closer together, and the protagonist learns to experience life once and awhile. Maybe there's conflict between his work and home life, and while they argue his watch shows up a lot. Maybe they get even closer and he starts to learn how to balance his life and then one day they're fucking and he has the watch on. It's rough though, his wrist hits something, and the watch breaks. His girl gets him a new one as a gift.

In this manner the watch is a talisman that provides basic structural cues on how the protagonist is running his life. It is an abstraction, but when we say it "represents his work-life balance, what we really mean is it acts as an emotional prompt. If it's well done, it should not be noticed by anyone who isn't explicitly looking. And it should be written for the people who won't notice it, not the ones who will
Anonymous

Here is chapter 3 of the hunter and his prey


>you stand up onto the platform breathing slowly a calmly but the adrenaline running through you is tell you to jump the shot. Each moment you take trying to look for the deer is another moment of rush you are taking from the thrill of the hunt.
>you can see the deer in the distance it is about 100 yards away from where you were.
>80…70…60…50…40 each 10 yards it takes from walking towards you is like a hit of a drug the feeling you have is blissful. This is your first deer ever and you were not going to let anything get in the way of it.
>30…25…20…15
>you can take the shot now that she is in full vision of you.
>you slowly draw the bow back into the anchor position, string to your cheek, the peep sight lined up perfectly.
>you get into stance. You move your front foot to the edge of the platform. That was your mistake.
>you hear the platform creaking.
>you can feel the screw in holder is coming loose from the tree.
>in a swift moment the platform is slanting downward towards the ground. You were a good 25 feet into the air.
>you hold onto the safety harness for dear life.
>the platform gives up on supporting you and falls to the ground, crashing loudly onto the forest floor with your gear.
>the safety harness catches you, But while catching you the strap goes under your neck and tightly constricts your neck hard.
>you are having a hard time breathing now that you have no place to step.
>you are trying to stay calm but the cut flow of oxygen is making it hard. You swing from the tree and into the air trying your best to gain some oxygen and not pass out.
>you struggle for about 4 minutes before you were so tired from doing it that you did not have enough strength to do so any more.
>you just hanged there awaiting your final moments.

Same. Eat just before bed, ideally cheese, meat, or other heavy foods. Booze also helps.

Keep pencil and paper by bed and write down the first thing you think when you wake up.

Chances are after a few times you'll realize you remember a dream you had.

I've never managed to lucid dream but I can at least get some fun dreams that way.

Keep doing that until you catch yourself dreaming; then work towards the usual tests to achieve lucidity like being able to push your hand through your other hand or if light switches work, etc.

I'm going to have an aneurysm trying to make traditional writing rules apply to green text. It's a medium that can get away with fucking murder while also being enough of a dick to straddle the rules just close enough that it's basically taunting with the notion of it behaving long enough to be proofread like normal material.

If I ever become famous, it'll be because I published a book of grammar rules for writing green text. Things like how many memes you can get away with in a single green, and when and when not to ignore basic punctuation and capitalization. Because sometimes greens just take a dump on logical sentence structure, but at the same time I can't judge it to harshly because it's a story written for >implication arrows and the short hand style of writing that usually follows them.
